A musty flavor of dirt and sugar. The mustiness sticks around well after each sip. A residual bitterness as well. Not sure if the musty flavor is from the spices or something else. But it is none to pleasant. Only thing wrong with this.

On tap at Brugs Beertje last Christmas. I drank plenty of this during my 3 night stay. A hazy/dark amber coloured pour with a medium beige head on top. Typical sweet Belgian yeasty aroma. Tastes sweet, fruity, malty, spice, caramel, cinammon. Nice and complex. A quality Belgian Christmas beer.
Bottle. Brown and poured with a big head.Some maltiness  which lingered for a long time. Straightforward with little complexity but still very interesting.

Tap. Pours deep copper with average white head; short retention and decent lacing. Aroma is yeast, cookie malt, pears, spice, and light grassy hops. Flavor is heavy malt, faint hops, and average fruit esters; slightly sweet finish. Medium body, carbonation, and warmth.

Pour off orange with decent white head. Aroma soft vanilla, light barrel notes, peppery, yeasty, spice, fruity. Taste wood, vanilla, dark fruits, bready yeast, pepper. MF medium body pretty high carb. Interesting brew with some strange tastes.

wow this is pretty wild. smokey fruit throughout. lots of smoke and funk and vanilla in the aroma. flavor is that plus dark fruits. nice medium body, chewy with a lingering smoked raisin finish. alcohol well-hidden but warming. really excellent.
Nice xmas beer. Spicy, but not over the top. Nice balance between hops, alcohol, spices and fruits

THOUGHTS: Very Belgian. Better than the original, but the original I had a couple years ago might have been bad. Woody and nutty both from the fruit pits. Very fruity, too.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a medium amber with a small to average head that mostly diminished, but left excellent lacing.It also had tiny to small particles of a thick density floating in the body. The aroma had light to moderate fruit syrup; hints of caramel; moderate floral, herbal, and perfume hops; slight minty hops; light to moderate spicy and dusty yeast; slight funky yeast; plum; mostly peach; wood and fruit pits. The initial flavor was moderately sweet and lightly acidic; while the finish was moderately sweet, moderately acidic and lightly bitter. There were peaches mostly, syrup, a little caramel, plum, cherry, alcohol, spicy yeast, herbal, floral and perfume hops; wood, nuts, fruit pits and slight funky yeast. The medium body was a little syrupy and sticky on the lips and then dry (especially toward the bottom of the bottle) with soft yet tingly carbonation and a light to moderate alcoholic finish.

33cl bottle. Dark amber with medium dirty white head. Nose : Excellent aromas of dried fruits and spices. There is this roasty caramel barley and some alcohol aromas. But there is something deep in it : the aroma of tree resin. Cream tart. Sip : The texture stays great, like the ordinary version of  Tsjeeses. The overall taste is more dry with stronger sourness in the aftertaste. The alcohol is warming like a whysky. Definitely the aging was a success and the difference is well noticeable : the wood aromas are present. 6 month hein ?

Medium sized head mity orange pour medium strong carbonation the enticing aromas are woody the oak very smooth caramel yeast good belgian strain gingerbread orange brown sugar clove cinnamon dried fruits brandy some sultana and raisin flavours are brandy raisin some sultana oak influence caramel bingerbread spicy with clove cinnamon brown sugar orange mild pepper so so good the finish a lovely bit of milling to fermenting work top aftertastes of hops spice sweet malts yeast brandy warmth oak smoothness light fizz cracking triple

Une palette aromatique tr√®s complexe : r√©glisse, √©pices, caramel, whisky, pain d¬í√©pices, vanille. Une bi√®re qui a du corps, Texture √† la fois liquoreuse et mousseuse. Un r√©gal! Trouv√©e √† Vanuxeem - Ploegstaert.

Draught pours honey color with minimal white head. Aromas are malty sweet and syrupy. Taste is malty caramel, oaky, and vanilla with a nice hop finish. Palate is medium with average carbonation. Finish is slightly bitter, but very balanced. Overall, a delicious brew.  I could drink lots of this one.

Slightly hazy, orange amber beer, beige head. Malty aroma, caramel, apricot, wood, vanilla and other spices. Flavour malty, slight wood astringency, caramel, and candy sugar. Finish slightly astringent with some lingering sweetness.
(From 33cl bottle @ home. 2011 vintage. Wondering how it will age, so will keep a few bottles for the next year(s).)
Poder beure cerveses com aquestes alegra el dia a qualsevol persona. Genial.

A hazed orange amber ale with a thin white head. In aroma, a sweet fruit caramel malt with treacle, light watermelon, OK. In mouth, a sweet smooth caramel with candy sugar, licorice, molasses, a tad of light coffee, alcohol warmth, not bad, but I was expected a bit more. On tap at Rattle¬ín¬íHum, Dec. 28 2011.

Aroma of applesauce, grapes, and slight cinnamon.  Strong nose.  Pours super hazy with a big frothy head.  Super big.  Tastes sweet of wheat, slight floral, and just a hint of spices.  Solid Belgian. Reminds me of a good champagne.

330cl Bottle Pour is hazy and reddish looking very christmas and with an initially frothy head which settled down to a light layer of froth. The aroma of cinnamon and oak also play the holiday part. Sweet flavor and sticky with holiday spices, yeast and oak. Creamy body, very nicely done!
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text:
Shared a bottle at the Bayou with my wife.
I prefer the regular Tsjeeses to the Reserva. I got notes of caramel, wood, butter, vanilla, smoke,cinnamon. There was a sticky mouthfeel to it as well. I had hoped for more and was disappointed. Maybe some age would do this beer some good.

Amber in color with a nice off-white head.  Intense wine aroma to this, almost like port.  A sweet grape aroma nearly overwhelms it.  Some vanilla as well as oak, caramel, toffee, and brown sugar.  Some overripe fruits in there, too.  The flavor is quite sweet with lots of oak, wine, grape, and plum flavors.  A touch of vanilla as well as the caramel/toffee, and brown sugar notes.  Medium bodied with medium carbonation.

Bottle. Rich amber beer with a dark cream colored head. Fruity aroma with yeast and light oak. Oak and citrus flavor with red fruit, malt, yeast, and spice. Medium bodied. Caramel and spice lingers with yeast, light citrus, and red fruit.

Thanks to grownfool for this one. Pours cloudy brown, with a loose white head. Smells like grape and some other fruity notes, oak, and...chestnuts? maybe? Tastes like candied grapes, oak and more chestnuts. Some bourbon and vanilla as it warms.

Even-toned apricot in color with a thin, dense white head, and an apple pear ester profile.  Taste is same, with an oddly well-blended woody astringency and alcohol bitterness.  Delicate and evaporative, but still substantial.  $9/11 oz

On tap at Gourmet Haus. Great plum and other dark fruit aroma, as well as estery aspects. Pours brown with off-white head. Slight lacing but head leaves quickly. Complex malt, dark fruit and sour combine nicely. Medium mouthfeel with yeast on back end.

Bottle produced in 2010 pours hazy ruby-orange with dense and creamy yet thin head.  Aroma has some musty sourness to it when the beer is too cold, but as it warms many more things become apparent; vanilla-oak, mushroomy earthiness, vinuous minerality/acidity/must, signature "green and purple grape" Struise yeast profile. 
Taste is incredibly different from the aroma with vanilla, mild malt vinegar acidity, syrupy sweetness, strawberry, biscuit, purple grapes, and a spice/herb profile that can only be described as "umami".  Body is medium, velvety, soft carbonation, complex mushroomy/spicy/barrely juicy finish.  Overall, every time I try a Struise beer, I am absolutely floored.  This is just as unique and complex as anything else I¬íve had from them.
(Bottle 20/12-2011) Very large white head, slightly unclear amber color, smooth taste. BB date 16-06-2016.

not sure of the vintage, had it at least a year so i am thinking ¬í09, says best before 12-12-12. pours a crisp clear reddish copper with minimal light orange head. drinks pretty well, slightly oaky, slightly spicey. nothing bad with it, but not all that memorable. a solid beer.

2011 bottle pour is hazy reddish with off white head, aroma brought notes of smoke, dark fruit, molasses, toffee and burnt toast, hints of oak and slight vanilla, some slight white fruit and spice notes in there as well.  Taste is a mix of dark fruit and white fruit, hints of caramel and toffee, oak and vanilla quietly poke their head in but the smoke also comes through to dry it out.  Interesting brew, not really tripel like but tasted pretty good.

On draft. Pour is murky gold with almost no head (could be the bartender). Aroma of fruity esters, light oak, vanilla, citrus, candi sugar. Taste is moderately sweet, caramel, fruity esters,vanilla, no oak flavor. Palate is dry, soft, lightly bitter finish. Quite nice though I don¬ít get much barrel.

Tap. Frothy white head, murky burnt orange. Bit spicy, vanilla, and orange in the aroma. Nice sweetness and slight spice and vanilla. Medium body with tight carbonation.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft at monk¬ís. Pours a clear amber pour with little head. Aroma is caramel with slight belgian spice. Flavor is very drawn out. Carmel highlights with a slight oak giving it a drawn out, long flavor. Pretty good oak aged  strong.

Bottle, pours dark honey, just a shade darker than the stndard Tjseeses, foamy off-white head, soft aroma of vanilla and stone fruit, similar flavor profile to the standard Tsjeeses but much more smooth an rich, delicious
Hazy light brown.  Slightly dark than tsjeeses.  Aroma is sort of brown sugary, vaguely barrelly.  Tastes similar - strong malty and then that ashtray stuff kicks in, ruining it for me.

Bottle. Nicer looking than the regular, a cinnamon red-orange. Thin lasting cap and scant lace. Aroma is hotter and not as inviting as the regular Tsjeeses. Totally different aromas. Smells like a cauldron due to an overpowering array of European witches¬í spices and booze. But the flavors are really nice, albeit with a boozy finish. Anise. Mace. Clove. Allspice. Bitter zest. Aftertaste defined by oakes as ashtray is certainly ashy with slight chalk on palate but like that left by spices, natural bitterness. Nice mulling spice profile. Too boozy but good.

Pours a cloudy amber with light sediment...medium tan head...nice retention and lacing.  Aroma has lots of light fruit...grape, apple...and some seasonal spice...cinnamon.  flavor has some spice and candi sugar...nice delicate hoppiness...hint of raisin...it starts out sweet and moves into spicy and then bitter.  Mouthfeel is medium and silky smooth and the finish has a great balance of malty sweetness and delicate hops.  This beer was actually tough to describe for me for some reason but damn tasty...much better than regular tsjeeses.

My mind was blown the first time I had the normal Tsjeeses a couple years ago and ever since I¬íve been wanting to try the reserva. Finally it hits stores on the west coast. This 33cl bottle pours a hazy orange color with a medium white head and high carbonation. Surprisingly smokey aroma with a hint of orange marmalade as well. Sweet juicy fruit sticks out and a little malt as well, but the fruitiness is pretty overriding. Boozy and sweet with a tannic and dry finish. A little yeasty and rough in the finish. I feel like I¬ím completely missing this one for some reason.

Bottle @ Bull and Bush Christmas tasting. Somewhat hazy, orange appearance with an off white head. Light meat smoky, caramel, toffee, spicy aroma. Meaty smoke, caramel, moderately fruity, toffee, caramel flavor. Strange that I got a bunch of smoke and the previous entries didn¬ít. 2011 vintage.

Bottle.  Hazy, chucky golden orange pour, with a large frothy head and good lacing.  Sticks a lot to the glass.  Candy like sweetness, fruit, spicy yeast, pepper, oak, citrus, bread, and caramel.  A pretty good tripel, I just don¬ít dig the style too much.

11.2 oz bottle from Cranbury BuyRite. Poured an unimpressive slightly hazed mostly orange/amber body with a smaller super light beige foamy head. Aroma really doens¬ít have much oak added to the Belgian yeast and strong malts which impart lots of raisin, dates, figs, grapes, nuts and bread but the hint of oak remains possible although not really a prescence in this beer. The body was a quick flash of copper followed by the quickest flash of oak with more easily detectable  soft carbonation. Flavor of yeast, grapes, prunes, plum, bad nectarines, nutts, breads, slight spice. This seems way more quad like then tripel but what do I know.
Orange body with large foamy head. Spicy and malty nose. Spicy and fruity taste. Very enjoyable.
2009 on tap at Capone¬ís. Pours muddy orange with whitish head. Aromas of orange, bread, pepper, nuts, pepper. Smooth bodied. Moderately sweet and bitter. Very nice.

33cl bottle (best before: 12/2012), tulip glass.
Pours a rather bubbly cloudy orange, with a white head and some visible sediment.
Smells of candi sugar, spice, bourbon and a hint of citrus.
Tastes of spiced oranges and caramel malt.
Creamy and full-bodied; finishes wet.
A beautiful and complex beer.

Shared this Shawn and Sean on our weekend trip to Antwerp @ the Kulminator.  Pours a hazy amber color. Aromas of bourbon, vanilla, wood, some fruit and spice. Taste is outstanding balance of sweet malts/fruits and some alcohol heat.

Pours hazy copper / brown with an off-white head.  The aroma has candy sugar, toasted malt, dark berries, oak, toffee, alcohol, spice and figs.  Medium / full body that¬ís rich with soft, but full, carbonation.  The flavor starts out with toasty malt, woodiness, caramel, toffee, peaches, nectarines, dark berries and hints of oak aging.  The finish some some alcohol warmth, spiciness, pears and vanilla.  Nice unique beer that sure doesn¬ít seem like a tripel to me.

(11.2oz bottle from AJs Arcadia).  Pours a cloudy dark orange-brown color with think white head. There is a good bit of small sedimentation in suspension.  Aroma is grape, sweet wine, wood, candied sugar and ripe berries.  Taste is sweet with more grapes and some metallic notes.  Light bitterness.  Full bodied with a sticky texture.  Super smooth finish.  Aside from the  slight metallic element, this is a superb beer!

Bottle @ √òlkonsortiet christmas beer tasting.  Pours dark golden with a offwhite head. Aroma of sweet bready malts, fruit, raspberries, vanilla. Taste is heavy sweet malts, caramel, sweets, fruit, raspberries, vanilla. Medium body, soft carbonation, light notes of alcohol. Very nice. 051111
heavy on the malts flavors. strong aroma with a thick palate and sweet malts. slight spicy but not very hoppy. still its an excellent beer.

The aroma is somewhat dry with malt, fruit, spice, charred wood and smoke. The appearance is copper with a foamy head. The taste is like the aroma. The palate is average for the style but good. Overall a good beer.
33cl bottle. Amber with a small white head. Smells and tastes fruity, sweet, apricose, abit alcohol with a similar finish.

Light honey pour with a razor thin head that diminishes to nothingness.  Aroma is faint Belgian yeast, spice, caramel, wood, and a little citrus.  Favor is similar, which isn¬ít tremendously exciting, but masks the alcohol well.  A touch of sweetness and zest...expected more but wasn¬ít terribly disappointed either.

Rating #651, flaske fra Fish N¬í Beer medbragt af Brian til julebrygsmagning 2011  

Kort fortalt, samme som den ulagrede version, bare med mere af det hele - specielt tr√¶smag og alkohol. Mundf√∏lelsen lader p√• en eller anden m√•de til at v√¶re blevet en smule tyndere. √òllen har stadig ikke meget med tripel at g√∏re, og selvom den bestemt er drikkelig, forst√•r jeg ikke at gennemsnitsvurderingen er helt s√• h√∏j som den er.
Draught @ Borefts 2011. Hazy, with amber color and no head. Fruity aroma with honey, wood, caramel and yeast. Medium dense and carbonated. Sweet, lasting finish. Good one.

[3994-20110925] 330mL bottle. Sweet caramel tea grain malt aroma. Hazy, dark brown body with a medium-lasting creamy off-white head. Boozy sweet floral toffee malt flavour with a long lasting heavily sweetened finish. Medium-full body. Interesting enough. (7/3+/7/3/14) 3.4+
(w/ jerc)

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2011 Bottle, quite the gusher even after sitting for almost a year.  Pours a murky,  unfiltered, dark apple cider color with brown highlights.  A lot of floaties in there too.  Strange aroma of a ton of oak, wet wood, grapes, and some sweet caramelized sugar.  Flavors caramel apples, burnt sugar, wet wood, and yeast are most pronounced.  In addition to the cider like qualities, theres almost a white wine aspect that it retains in its finish due to the oak.  Starts off sweet and finishes dry and tannic.  Interesting for a triple.  Was a little worried at first, but I dig.

2011-09-25. Murky amber body foams out of the bottle, small beige head after it settles down. Sweet malt, caramel touches, modest malt, light alcohol, lightly spicey, kiss of brandy or cognac like alcohol character? 7+ Flavour is similar, sweet malt with caramel and sugary touches. Dry edges and modest alcohol throughout, light hints of wood and something I can¬ít place in the background. Bit of liquor like alcohol touches. Smooth average plus to medium bodied palate is softly carbonated. 3+ Nice but not what I am looking for today apparently.  Bottle, approximately a year old from bottle shop in Brussels
bottle, amber coloured with nice foamy white head. Smell: very nice hops and great fruityness. Taste: hoppy, orange peel, some sweetness, yeasty. Very complex but great one!

Pours an amber color with off white head and some chunks.  Aroma is cane sugar, apple brandy, Bread.  Taste is quite sweet and smooth with apple and floral notes and a malty sweet finish.  Much better then the regular version imo.
Sweet aroma. Lightly bready, spicy, great flavors. Apple. Dry finish, a little thick.
Bottle, thanx to Marsiblursi. Pours hazy golden with a small, white head. Fruity, malty, sweet aroma, raisins, marzipan. Malty to the taste, ginger, oak, marzipan, alcohol. Fruity, low bitterness.

Bottle... Mostly clear, light amber ale with a small, creamy, white head. Excellent retention. The sharp, acidic bouquet furnishes golden raisins floating in a sea of calvados. Full-bodied and creamy with subdued carbonation. The flavor is nutty and full of sweet caramel layered upon undercurrents of calvados and oak. Finishes sweet and tangy; fruity and caramely. Bottle courtesy of darkguardian!

11/1/10 from gene.
hazy orange brown with a small white head.
it smells spicy!... anise, ginger, cinnamon, black pepper, vanilla and alcohol mixed with brown sugar, fruity tartness and plums.
the palate is relatively sweet but it has a tartness and a bit of tannic drying on the finish... otherwise the flavor is the same as the aroma. 
thick and smooth... nice.7/4/7/3/16

Pours a two finger light khaki head that fades slowly to a thin layer leaving some lace. Medium carbonation and medium bodied.  Hazy amber color with a ton of yeast left in bottle.  Nose is sweet, fruity and flavor is malty, spicy, some dark fruit. High ABV is hidden. Much better than the Tsjeeses. Pricey at $9.95 for a 330ml bottle from Colonial Spirits, Acton, MA.

Bottle shared thx to Marsiblursi 2011-07-09 S√§tila
AR: pommac, rasines, champagne, cognac, marzipan, honey
AP: honey, wee beige head
F: goose berries, caramel, mandarins, maderia, oak, tokaj wine

Bottle. Pours copper with a lacy off-white head.  The aroma is oaky with sweet fruity notes--white raisin, lime, nectarine; there is also some vanilla, caramelized sugar, and pleasant floral quality.  The flavor is spicy yeast with some wild fruity notes and obvious oak. There is a mild brown sugar sweetness, but it¬ís cut by the attenuated dryness. The finish is vanilla and tannin with some nice alcoholic warmth (but no boozy burn). Some fruity esters and Raisin Bran cereal make the aftertaste. Pretty good stuff.

330 ml bottle. BBE 12.12.2012. Rated @¬†24.6.2011.
Pours a dark golden colour with a thick white head. Aroma of sweet dried fruits and some mild spices. Flavour of sweet caramel malts, mild spices, dried fruits and oak. Very smooth and thick mouthfeel and a long, fruity, oaky finish. Overall a smooth brew which lacks taste a bit.

Bottle; Pour is dark, murky golden with a very nice off white head that retains in an excellent fashion into this snifter, with fine bubbled lace present as I progress through this one slowly. There is a bit of earthiness from the oak, as well as a fruity nature from peaches, combined with candied sugars. The oak really imparts terrific flavor for this one with vanilla; also present is a bit of earthiness, brown sugar, candied sugar, grassy hops, and general fruit esters. I think this may be my favorite Tripel, thus far.

Reviewed from notes.
Poured into a tulip glass. The color is a slightly-hazed light caramel color. Good white head and plenty of lacing as it falls. The nose brings a nice yeast presence as well as some fruit and semi-sweet light malt. The taste is a bit of yeast and fruity esters along with mild booze and some malt. Really nice feel with excellent yeast presence. Really nice beer overall; I have yet to be disappointed by De Struise.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-09-2010

Tasted on 3/29/11 from a 330mL bottle purchased at West Lakeview Liquors.  Pours cloudy, very light amber with a thick white head that slowly recedes to thin lace, leaving residue along the inside of the glass.  The nose is sweet caramel along with banana, spicy yeast, brown sugar, bread, and clove.  The flavor is lightly sweet with caramel, brown sugar, bread, honey, banana, spicy clove, and pitted fruits with some light bitterness.  The body is full and sticky with average carbonation and a long pitted fruit, biscuit, and bitter finish.

2010 bottle drank from a tulip...Pours much darker than the regular version, murky dark gold with a nice head...Yeast is prominent on the nose, the backbone. There is also a very vinous quality, dry white wine, grapes, smooth with a hint of spice. Takes the regular version and just improves it...The taste is equally nice, a little smooth bourbon, yeast, coriander, apples, spices, so incredibly smooth and complex. Not totally what I was expecting off the nose, but really good...This is another awesome De Struise worth trying.
Tap at Lord Hobo.    Lightly peppery nose coming off of a pale golden amber pour.  Spice and oak, but it seems a little bit thin to me.

Murky Orange glowing pour.  Head is thin and dissipates quickly. Aroma is yeast, apricot, candi sugar, tell tale de struise yeast.  Mouth feel is prickly, flavor is candi, apricot skin, fruit.  Apparently they throw apricot pits into this so it makes sense.  Finish is the best part, vinious, rich sweet malt, bread.  Damn good.

330 ml bottle from michael-pollack- thanks again, Pollack! Pours a cloudy, dark orange color with some small visible yeast sediment and a big eggshell-white head that leaves some light lace. Aroma of caramel malts, Belgian yeast, orange peel, alcohol, mild spice, and oak. Flavor of apricots, caramel malts, candi sugar, Belgian yeast, oak, mild spices, and corn syrup. Medium-bodied, with a sweet, malty, sugary mouthfeel and moderate carbonation. Alcohol can¬ít really be felt in the mouth until the aftertaste. Sweet, unique tripel.

33cl traded bottle of unknown vintage at cellar temp. Left the lees in the bottle. Wow, this is a pretty powerful tripel.  Perfectly brewed to form but amped up sweetness, fuller mouthfeel, spice and alcohol heat. It¬ís an eye-opener!
Bottle at Max¬ís.  Hazy orange yellow pour.  Belgian cherry aroma with some alcohol.  Smooth creamy flavor.  Light sweetness, though tons of alcohol.  A bit of butter.  Meh.

Bottle 330ml @ home
Pours murky golden with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt and dried fruits. Taste is medium to heavy sweet and light bitter. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.
caramel popcorn nose, some big oak. hazy dijon mustard in the glass, nearly absent head. big toffee body saturated in oak. tannic finish.
Deilig jule√∏l som  smaker tydelig av belgisk gj√¶r, god s√∏dme, men kunne hatt lengre ettersmak.  Fin  √∏l!
Hazy deep amber color pour with a ring of frothy head.  Aroma of dark ripe fruit, caramel malt, yeast and a touch of spice.  Lightly sweet fruity flavor with nice yeast and spice notes.  Very good.

330 ml bottle, a gift from gunnar, many thanks! ABV is 10.0%. Very cloudy brown colour, big off-white head. Strong sweetish aroma of Belgian ale yeast and a complex symphony of spices, also notes of honey and dark dried fruits. The flavour is fairly sweet with notes of spices, brown candi sugar, caramel and oak. Good stuff!

Pours a deep, dark copper orange with golden burnt orange hues when held to a light source and a two finger frothy yellowish, off-white head. Much darker than the regular version with visible carbonation bubbling up. Excellent retention, only slowly fading into a lasting cap.

Slightly earthy, spicy aroma with a decent malt backbone, slight medicinal character and estery fruit notes. Lots of spice, especially peppermint, cinnamon, clove, coriander and pepper. A nice combination of light and dark fruit but the darker fruits ae more prominent. Hints of cherry, apple, pear, grape, currant, plum, raisin and fig. Although these fruit notes are evident they are less prominent than in the regular version. The Reserva smells much more earthy and spicy and the aroma suffers a bit from this. There¬ís also more of a medicinal cough syrup and sweet alcohol presence.

Medium bodied and well balanced with a nice combination of zesty spice, caramel malt, estery fruit and alcohol heat. Tight carbonation up front with a lot of spice. Hints of pepper, corriander, clove, peppermint and ginger linger throughout into the finish. This is balanced by a slight creamy body with a medicinal and dark fruit flavor that adds complexity and fullness to the mouthfeel. I¬ím picking up hints of cherry, currant, grape, plum, raisin and other dark berries. The dark berries overpower the lighter fruits in this beer much more than the regular version and there is substantially a bit more alcohol sweetness and warmth in the finish. Overall this beer is pretty good and I¬ím glad that I finally got a chance to try it after two years of searching, but I have to say that I prefer the regular version a bit more.

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2011 well hidden alcohol behind a veil of hazy copper-gold. slightly dry but rich, well balanced and dangerously drinkable.
Additional 2010 aged 1 year - Nice, but a tad too much honey sweetness.
2011 - Less sweet, more balanced.  Actually, blending 50/50 with the 2010 was just about perfect :)

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2012 Subtle blond with light winey-woody aroma.  Honey-gold with a solid white head and nice lace.  A lighter beer, grape and wood, moderately sweet with a dry, slightly earthy finish and nice wood notes.

Notes" ¬í09 release, bordeaux barrell

330ml Bottle:  Sweet aroma of Belgian yeast, malt, fruit, slight cocoa, slight oak, and slight caramel.  Poured copper/amber in color with a small, creamy, dense, off-white head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Very sparkling.  Flavor is heavily sweet.  Tastes of yeast, Belgian malt, light fruit, slight funk, and slight oak.  Medium to full body.  Viscous, creamy, texture.  Soft to average carbonation.  Medium sweet, malt, fruit, yeast, finish is slightly dry.  10%ABV is completely hidden throughout.

Draft at Belgian with Linh. 09 vintage. Pours bright hazy orange body with thin white lacing. Aroma is light refreshing  fruits. Mouthfeel is smooth, balanced and light with notes of Belgian candy and fruits.
special beer indeed. Aroma is very sour and strange. some vinous and fruity notes. In the taste you get the stuff from the aroma along wioth some wood, spices and a barley wine kinda finish. Funny :)
Pours a hazy orange with a thin off-white head. Nice fruity aroma.  Full bodied and lively on the palate.  Tastes of ginger, brown sugar, cinnamon, and orange.  Nice long finish.

2008  - 750 bottle.  Its been well cellared for 2+ years.  I meant to drink this last xmas but finally got to it this year.  I think I waited a year too long.  Big oaky + fruity nose.  Very little carbonation/head.  slightly cloudy orange body.   Thin body with a slight almost sour finish that I like.  Its starting to show some significant oxidation.   The oxidation is just killing this beer for me as I do not like oxidation at all.  The thin body and showing almost no alcohol makes this 10% beer very easy to drink.  The age probably helped it here.   I want to revisit a fresh bottle with less than a year on it....i could see really liking this beer.

Bottle from Secret Santa!  A good one for the holiday season.  Pours a murky golden-brown color with a thick fluffy head.  Thick spotty lacing coats the glass.  The aroma shows lots of ripe fruit, apple and citrus seems to stand out.  Flowers, herbs, candi sugar, belgian yeast round out the scent.  The flavors follow.  Ripe citrus and tart apple combine with candi and brown sugars, belgian yeast, and assorted spices.  After opening this right after the regular version, I have to be honest, there isn¬ít a lot of difference.  A mild wood-oaky note does present itself here and overall this one might be slightly more refined and mellow.  The two are very close though.

I thought it was pretty cool to run into this beer at Binny¬ís/  Pours a hazy golden, that in certain lights looks more like a dull burnt orange.  Aroma of  strong wood, some slight fruit, a bit of piercing spice.  Some light smoke.  Flavor has a strong oaky presence.  Oak-aging is obvious but not overwhelming.  A bit of spice, some nice fruitiness.  Overall, the oak is on display here, but very nice.

On tap at louisville beer store.  Pours golden/amber with a lacy head.  Aroma of alcohol, light fruit, and some hops.  Flavor sweet, like a dessert wine, with alcohol undertones.  Creamy texture.  A great beer.

330 ml bottle; thanks to grownfool for the trade; clear dark gold pour with thick, egg white head fading slowly; dense light brown in the glass; aromas of sweet candy malt, white sugar, spicy lemon, earthy phenols; spicy flavors with sugary dried fruits and chewy malt; definitely sweet, but there is a deep smoothness and creamy texture to it and the sweetness level is just about perfect; oaky dry finish with vanilla cookies, lemons and sugary malt; quite nice overall
Pours deep amber into a snifter. Off-white head recedes to hug rim. Dark pit fruit and oak aromas. Sweet dark oaked pit fruit covered caramel soaked in earthy candi.
33 cl bottle. Hazy golden with off-white head. Flavour is malt, sweet, caramel, fruit, wood and spices.

Dark hazy orange pour with a large white head. Lots of vinous dark fruit and barrel notes in the aroma with an ever present spicy yeasty dough. The flavor holds tons of dark fruit plums, raisins, and grapes with more vinous barrel and spicy yeasty dough. A delicious quaff.
Nose of weak port, rotten fruit, feel and carb are medium, taste is mild cherry, plum, alcohol and late weak sweet hops.

Bottle at √òlKonsortiet Christmas tasting Aroma has some very obvious yeast components, orange peel, cinnamon, raspberries. I have a hard time finding the oak. Taste is rather sweet and spicey, and the yeast really shines trough, orange peel and christmas spices. Really easily drinkable and very good.

Huge thanks to Gene for this one! Bottle pours cloudy burnt amber with an off-white head.  Aroma is fruity and malty, with notes of caramel, bread, and dusty yeast.  Flavor shows the same with additional notes of orange peel, marshmallow, and a pinch of caramelized brown sugar.  Overall body is full and creamy with light to moderate sweetness, no real bitterness, and a touch of alcohol.

Courtesy of Gene! Nice to meet you! Hazy caramel colored pour, Nice fruity aroma with some caramel, bready notes, yeast.  Flavor is a nice mix of yeast, stone fruit, caramel, yeast, bready notes.  Good shit!

Kerstbierfestival 2009. Pours a clear dark golden color with copper highlights and floaties, the head is thin and offwhite. Aroma of wood, citrus, yeast and spices with some sweetness. Solid flavor of wood, citrus, yeast and spices with some sweetness. The body is light to medium with a vinous texture and soft carbonation. Very good.

head: semi creamy , beige 
colour: orange/amber, dusty 
smell: malts, coconut, alcohol, sweet, almunds, grains, salt 
taste: creamy, coco flavour in the start, malty bitter, alcoholic, and sweet in middle, oranges, punching strong and alcoholic in the end , aftertaste is dry , earthy and grassy

Had this one from 2010 from keg as well as an older one from bottle, both at BBF. First tried the keg one, which was a welcome brew after an overdose of IPAs and imperial stouts. Smooth, soft tripel with a fair amount of sweetness and some fruit. Bottled one was more matured and much sweeter, but I preferred the other one.

Walk in some farmers market in the middle of nowhere and there is a WRC car and ONLY Struise beer for sale. Nothing that cool would ever happen in the middle of nowhere round my way. Poured by Urbain, ta very much. Slightly hazy orange with pretty much no head. Aroma and flavour are very complex. Perfectly carbonated for the style. Spices, vanilla, apple, caramel, lovely amount of sweetness. Delicately balanced. Perfectly drinkable and would love to get my hands on large quantities right now. Being skint, I get a lonely bottle to cradle home.

Appearence - pours a murky caramel-coloured body, fine off-white head. Aroma - nose is very fragrant, full, malty, sugary, ripe fruits, vinous, caramel, toffee, hint of vanilla, oak, a bit of alcohol burn. Palate/Flavour - body has a medium-full presence, fine foamy/slick, flavours are mainly malty ripe fruits, very similar to the nose, overripe fruit (apple, pear) sticks in the finish. Overall - pretty malty for a tripel, does hide the 10% well.

Bottle pour at Stillwater event @ Spuyten Duyveil. Golden brown pour with some light head. Yeasts, fruit, woody, spices and sweet caramel and fruit esters aromatics. Flavor is fruity and sweet with a moderate warming.

330 ml bottle courtesy of a BA trade.  Pours a hazy golden orange color with a fine off white head.  The aroma was sweet, candi sugar, floral, caramel and mild dark fruits.  The flavor has caramelized sugar, figs, nutmeg and some other spices, oak, and hints of alcohol.  It opens tingly, but the finish is dry.  Medium bodied.  Not my favorite, but I am glad to have had the opportunity to try this.

Consumed 7/16/2009 (from notes)
Bottle. Amber colour with a beige head. Aroma is alcohol, spices, caramel. Flavour is sweet, malt, yeast, buillon, spices, caramel, alcohol, fruit. Full body. Harmonic nice beer.

UPDATED: JUL 23, 2010 75cl bottle courtesy of Urbain shared with Travlr, Owen, Herman and Sebastien. Vintage 2008. Goldblond with almost no head. Fruity aroma with grapes, wine, oak and a slight citrus note. Taste is sweet and fruity with wine touches and a slight alcohol precense.  Fruity wine finish. Wonderfull beer!

retasting of a 33cl bottle vintage 2007, courtesy of Urbain shared with David.

Bottle from Boutip - thanks, Phil! Alas, only a few ounces survived the trip (through absolutely no fault of Phil¬ís!) and so I decided to sample the remainder on my lonesome (was hoping to bring this one to a tasting). Cloudy deep orange pour, some lingering sediment visible, and not much carbonation at all. Strong aroma of apple and yeast, like not fully baked apple pie with some serious tartness to it. Taste is a bit boozy, again laced by the tart apples and just a hint of spice. A bit of the wood comes through towards the finish. From what I can tell, nicely done, moderately tweaked yeasty tripel. Will actively seek out again.

Bottle (thanks to Tweety)...  Poured hazy, golden/orange with a fluffy, white head.  Nose was very wine-like, hints of sweet, spiced yeast tones, sour apples, and brown sugar.  Very fruity, wonderful spiced esters.  Black pepper, a little alcohol heat, grapes, apples, and some dark, malt tones. Very lovely brew.
Bottle: Poured a coppery hazy mess with a off white lacing head. Aroma is aged fruit, woods, and spice. Sweet sticky fruit with woods and spice. Tingle on the finish!

Bottle from Frank Smith¬ís.  Pours turbid pumpkin pie color w 1f frothy ow head.  Nose is tart fruit, hops, florals, yeasty root cellary esters, coriandery spice.  Tastes rock sugary malty, floral, fruity, spicy,herbal, very sticky, a bit cloying late, thick, and complex.

Bottle.

A - Cloudy, murky golden, orange, beige mixture for color. Fairly large foamy and creamy slightly off-white head. Average retention with a nice thin layer of foamy and sticky lace.

S - Wet grainy and bready malt. A touch of fruitiness (in particular apple and orange but some other golden fruit). Some woodiness and earthiness along with a good amount of spice and vanilla. Good amount of yeast and sweetness.

T - Similar to the nose. Bready pale malt and wet grainy taste. Fruity flavors present but not overly strong with apple and orange strongest but some peach, apricot, pear, etc. Some spice of clove, coriander, cinnamon and pepper along with a strong yeast flavor. 

M - Medium body with a good amount of carbonation. Fairly smooth.

D - Very drinkable beer that is quite balanced. ABV is well hidden and it goes down easy.

Notes: Best before 12/12/12. Well balanced beer with a good amount of malt, fruit, and grain taste along with hints of woodiness and earthinesss. Not really like other BSPAs and it is pretty interesting, especially with the hints of woodiness. I wasn¬ít fully blown away by the beer, but it was an enjoyable beer.

330 ml bottle. Hazy, dark golden body with a big off-white head. Aroma of sweet malt, yeast, fruit, spices and alcohol. Flavor is sweet malt, spices, yeast, ripe fruit and alcohol. Almost no bitterness, still complex and a long, sweet and warming finish.

Thanks to Keith for the 33cL bottle, BB 12/12/12.  Poured hazy, deeper sienna with a tight-bubbled cap of whitish head.  The aroma had significant freshly-cut oak and lighter-skinned fruit tartness throughout.. light fruit meat, vanilla, and a pinch of molasses supported.. somehow soft on the nose despite the hefty components, which is testament to a well-made brew.  The flavor also found tart fruit skins and oak all the way through.. toffee, fruit, and vanilla supported.. white pepper and clovey spices joined more barrel character on the edges.. lots more fruity sugars on the finish.  Medium-plus bodied with tight, rolling carbonation on the palate.. I love what the spice notes and barrel character did here, but in the end there was just a little too much sweetness.  Overall a very, very good brew.

Tsjeeses, this is a good beer - even better than Tsjeeses.  Then again, does -bal aging ever fail?  Rarely it seems.  33cl bottle came from De Bier Tempel Brugge in the July of 2009.

Pours a mostly clear orangish-amber color with a nicely formed off-white head and good lacing.

Aroma is really awesome with a lot going on.  Caramel, toffee, sweet apple, spice, and vanilla, with no one flavor too dominant over the rest.

Flavor is also very nice and balanced.  Caramel and toffee malt notes, with Belgian yeast, sweet candy apples, cinnamon and other spices, banana/fruity esters, oak, and vanilla.

Very smooth mouthfeel with medium-full bodied and an appropriate carbonation level.

Overall, this one is a real winner.  Really enjoyable.

Bottle from Beer Planet. Explosive cloudy dark orange pour with a fluffy beige head. Sour, woody aromas with hints of apple, cinammon, caramel and heather. Flavours of toffee, caramel, citrus, candied peel, malts. Very, full on warming alcohol. This is certainly warming the parts other beers don¬ít normally reach! Very nice sweet, spicy throat massage finish.

Gift from my Secret Santa Winter 2010.  AWESOME!  Pours a perfect yeasty brownish gold from the bottle - plenty of sediment through and through.  Nose is thick with beautiful yeast (custard, apple sauce, cinnamon).  Flavor is quite deep: leather, mulled apple, cinnamon, dark flowers, a great Tripel character and nice, moldy, mellowed wine wood.  Nice.

33 cl bottle. Pours hazy orange red coloured with a small white head. Fruity aroma of spices and marzipan with notes of alcohol. Sweet and fruity flavour of spices, yeast, oak, marzipan and alcohol. Spicy and warming alcoholic finish.

Sweet and sour notes in the aroma; as a concentrated hoegaarden (good).

Thick(!) unexpected for tripple.

Fantastic balance, alcohol hidden, sweet and sour, not bitter or alcoholic.

Very nice. Wintery thick, yet fresh. 

Purchased in √òlbutikken.

Bottle 25 cl.Pours amber orange with floaters.Aroma of spice ,yeast and herbs.Flavor is beef-stock with a lot of malt and sweet and sour notes.Some alcohol warmth.Medium body , soft carbonation.Nice beer.

Bottle shared by chriso sampled on 3/6/10: Pours a hazy deep bronze orange with a spotty-lacing off-white head.  Aroma of sweet complex dark caramel and brown sugar with some black cherry.  Starts with good rich caramely and toffee complexity with some nice fruity esters and oak before a full, slightly warming finish.  Very complex, balanced and enjoyable.

33cl bottle sampled at the DC Local tasting.  Pours a cloudy, orange amber with a creamy white head.  Boozy aroma, banana, Belgian yeast.  Flavor is sweet, boozy, candy, honey.  I don¬ít get any oak in either the nose or the flavor.  Full bodied with a lasting sweetness.

The bottle looks great as well as the beer in the glass. Orange-brown, a bit cloudy, nice head. Starts strong but not alcoholic. Very spicy from the beginning with notes of christmas spices, cinnamon, nuts and ginger snap. Also fruity notes of raisins. Very well balanced warming finish. An awesome brew!
33cl bottle, thanks chriso.  Cloudy apple juice body, medium, persistent off-white head.  Aroma is medium sweet, Bourbon, strawberry, light vinous, caramel.  Medium body.
Light barrel aging characteristics show up in the aroma - toffee and vanilla.  Creamier than regular Tsjeeses with a light sweetness.
UPDATED: MAR 23, 2010 Lots of oak, fairly dry, light cotton candy, herbal hops. Actually not too bad, decent BA¬íd beer.

Bottle, at Mes¬ís. Hazy bronze coloured with a lingering thin white head.  Loads going on here in all departments. Complex and gradually unfolding elements that draw you in ever further with each sip. Yeasty  and woody aroma with loads of christmasy booze soaked fruit and something else quite strange I couldn¬ít put my finger on, almost like a fresh set of michelins lurking. Sweet and full bodied flavour, with again loads happpening; spices, blood orange, cinnamon, manuka honey, wood, more booze.  A stonkingly well crafted take on a Tripel Dig the smoky santa.......

Big thanks to zathrus13 for this!  Poured into a snifter as dark gold/orange with only slight carbonation that dissipated quickly and left no lacing.  Aroma of nice citrus, some darker fruit (fig/date), bready yeast, and an all around crisp nose.  Taste has many of the same characteristics but with a more pronounced alcohol presence and sugar.  A thick, deeper taste than the nose lets on.  Overall, beautiful for a tripel.  A great brew.

(bottle shared by OSLO) Pous a hazy dark brownish gold with a substantial white head.  Aroma is potent with scents of sugar cookies, peaches, banana, honey, candi sugar, alcohol, and a substantial oak presence as well.  The bready yeast character is subdued on this one when compared with the regular Tsjeeses.  The taste begins with candi sugar, banana, pear, and stale bread crust tartness, that finishes out with a significant wood presence.  Spices are present too, and the oak successfully dries out all of the sweetness present in the mid-palate.  Mouthfeel is full and carbonation is lively.  Good stuff indeed, but the barrel tamps down the great yeast complexity which was present in the regular.  Thanks Al!
Sparkling orange-brown body with at small white rock y head. Fruity aroma, apricot, caramel, brown sugar. Spiced. The palate is sticky. Warming. The taste es heavy sweet, light bitter and light acid.
A nice murky color with caramel malts, yeast, and candy sugar.  A spicy body with hints of oak on the finish.  A little bit of belgian yeast in the body.

[Bottle] Pours cloudy orangish-brown with an off-white head. Aroma has a lot of banana like the original Tsjeeses, but it is toned down. That fruitiness blends very nicely with the oak and though the alcohol is present, it isn¬ít overpowering.  The banana is even more restrained in the taste, with yeast, decent bitterness, oak, and malt. Nothing too exciting to describe, but done very well and enjoyable. Medium thin mouthfeel, decent finish and quite dry. Really good, but not quite as good as the original.

Bottle. Much pressure in the bottle and it nearly exploded out of the bottle. Huge pale brown head and unclear cloudy amber colour with lots of yeast floating around. Aroma sweet, raisins, bubblegum, sugar. Taste sweet malty, brown sugar quite warming alcohol, some bubbles in the finish. As always I don¬¥t really see the great idea in ageing in tree barrels. I remember the original version as better.
330 ml bottle a hazy yellow orange colored beer with a white head aroma of oak fruit and sweetness taste fruit sweetness a light bitter en light oak a full tasting ending.

Bottled 33cl. Murky orange with a lot of impurities floating in the glass. Metallic vinous aroma with hints of oak. Quite a lot of marmite showing up in the taste. Overly sweet and sticky. The oak doesn¬ít add anything to this beer- in the contrary: it just destroys its subtlety. Slightly unpleasant yeasty finish which is reminiscent of mackerel . Very dissapointing- the regular tsjeeses is a lot better.

Bottle. Pours a very  murky orange / caramel with minimal head. No locaing. Aronmas are very complex. Some sour cherry, dark fruit and typical belgium yeast type aromas. Flavours initially sour cherry more dark fruit and bready yeast. Certainly a very complex beer though not really getting the oak.

33 cl bottle. Pours hazy deep golden with a big frothy white head. Weak yeasty almost fruity aroma. Very heavy deep dark malty taste, weak sweet.
Finish is light bitter sweet with some alcoholic hints. Full ending. Nice and drinkable.

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2010 An awesome, high-fermented beer from De Struise. A lot of sediment floating around in my bottle so this was risky. The complexity was thankfully astonishing. A superb beer. Very special. Luckilly I have one more in my stock to try so will review more comprehensively at a later time. I hope that one is better on the eye. I got a lot of sour fruits, tart, zest peel and raisins Edit. Borefts version. 2009. WOW. Oakier, fuller, less sediment, still a little clouder but wow, such an improvement. Up this to a 4.5. Cheers.
Murky orange beer with a lasting white head, aroma is sweet, bready, fruity and alcoholic with a sweet (jammy) faintly woody - fruity taste......all in all a cracker.

Deep golden blonde beer, very hazy and with big white mousse.  Aroma is fantastic and very complex. Hints of wood, fruits, spices, hops and sweet bread. Taste is rich, bready and fruity. Hints of wood, cognac and fruit in the finale.

From a 75 cl bottle, Loads of yeast cediment in the bottle. Hazy orange golden / amber beer with big white head on top. Aroma is complex, cake like, lots of cereals, bit of cognac, pepper, yeast and fruits. Taste is warming, with a fine caracter of malts, bread, some pepper and fruits, a slight bit of citrus fruits too. Ends with a soft bittering.

16-NOV-2009, bottle @D√òE m√∏de, Vanl√∏se.
Orange, hazy, high off-white head.
Sour nose and under that vanilla, oranges, sour apples, and tons of more stuff. Really complex.
Loads of dried fruits, champagne-like carbonation that is quite high. Very very creamy, extremely complex with layer after layer. LOOOOONG aftertaste.
Beer of the night.

Pale orange colour with a absolutely huge off-white head. Aroma is caramell and oaky vanilla with spicy and yeasty notes. Moutheel is generous with a proper amount of carbonation to keep things drinkable. Flavours are caramell, wood, vanilla and fruity yeast esters. Rather drinkable with very little sign of the high ABV.

A - Pours a hazy copper with a single finger of off white head. It then recedes to a thing web and with light lacing.

S - Oak, apple, plums, candi sugar, clove, and a bit of alcohol.

T - Not as overpowering a the smell would lead on, but definitely more complex than the standard Tsjeeses. Oak, apples and candi sugar, with the spice and alcohol taking the backseat.

M/D - Low carbonation gives the beer a sticky full mouthfeel and fits perfect for the overall flavor. The oak aging made this much better than the standard Tsjeeses. Unbelievably drinkable Christmas beer. I just wish I would have bought more bottles. 

The Belgians definitely have a different take on barrel aging, which usually just lends flavor without over powering it like so many American brewers. All of Struise¬ís BA offerings have been phenomenal in my book.
Courtesy Jim Richart of Southern Brew News. Tsjeeses with hints of vanilla and wood and no alcohol. Solid holiday brew.
Bubble gummy, light fruits, with a sugary sweetness on the nose.  Pours a cloudy golden orange with a thin white head.  Very sweet malts, hints of spicy yeast with traces of oaky vanilla.  Not bad.

0.33 L bottle. Opaque, dark golden-orange body. Low beige head fading to filmy layer of foam. A fine fruitiness in the aroma, oranges and lemonade. A noticable yeast scent, some spices, and a pleasant whiff og marzipan and roasted nuts. Taste is medium malty, rounded, both sweet and light sour. Generously spiced. Less bitter than original version. Some subtle wooden notes, and a refined fruitiness underneath. Alcohol well masked. Fat body. Finishes on the drier side, fruity and spicy with a touch of wood. A complex, tasty and well-crafted beer. Very nice indeed.
Pours cloudy golden with an off-white head. Aroma is light malt, spices, fruits, and light acidic. Flavour is caramel, alcohol, spices, vanilla, clove and coriander, and fruits.
Bottle. Hazy amber colour with a nice off white head. Rich aroma and taste of fruits, malts, yeast and spices with a slightly alcoholic finish.
Clear amber of color with an off white head. An aroma of malt, sweets, orange, spice and dry notes. A flavor of orange, spice, yeast and dry.

This orange beer was something I would have never expect. The taste is really penetrating, so I would advise to try this at the end of an evening, since I still tasted it the morning after. It¬ís just incredible!

Bottle  Orange/amber body.  Frothy, off-white head.  Quite fastly diminishing.  Lots of yeast particles.  Aroma of apple, caramel, citrus, brandy, grappa, bourbon, white wine (alsace like - gewurtztraminer/pinot gris): very complex and extremely well balanced.  Moderately sweeet, lightly bitter flavour consisting mainly of caramel flavours with a malty touch.  Very nice, well balanced flavour with a nice complexity.

Poured a tijuana river yellow. 
Nose was very faint in oakiness with a giant bready yeast. 
Taste was very true to smell, small oak tastes, bit on bread and yeast with a pleasant hint of peach.

(Bottle, Gollem, Amsterdam, 2 Aug 2009) Cloudy orangey brown colour with frothy, beige head. Malty nose with notes of dried fruit (apricots, raisins), brown sugar and hints of oak and vanilla. Malty, fruity taste with dried fruit, dried apricots, burnt sugar, hints of wood lurking in the background and a spicy, malty, slightly vinous finish. Full body, sweet with a balanced spicy bitterness. Tasty, warming and very nice beer.

Bottle, thanks Keith! Pours cloudy gold/orange, with a white head. Aroma is oak, yeast, and some spices. Flavor is fruit, spices, yeast, alcohol, oak, and a little bit of hops. Medium to heavy body. None of the flavors come jumping out at you, but the subtlety of all of them together make this work for me.
Bottle.  Probably at WeeHeavy¬ís.  Sweet.   flowery aroma.  Really cool aroma.  Easy to drink.  Great aroma.
Time to catch up before BCTC. On tap at Spuyten Duyvil big beer fest. Warm leathery sugary aroma.   Candy sugar w tobacco bitterness and bitter finish.  Pretty good.

Bottle tried side by side with the regular version.  Pours a hazy deep orange amber with a good sized off white head leaving some spotty lacing.  Nose of neutral oak, citrus, banana, and light clove spice.  Flavors of slightly sweetened oak, with some citrus and banana, again a big yeasty finish .

Sampled at the Struise brewery in Belgium poured from a 750 in May 08, now again from a bottle I brought home today.  Pours a Dirty straw brown color w/ lots of visible carbonation and a bit of sediment along w/ a perfect thick off white head w/ great lacing.  Aroma is light orange zest some apricot, some light pepper, allspice, and a hint of wood.  Nice creamy well coated palate.  Flavor is much more spiced than I remember.  Lots of peppers some orange zest lots of caramel, a light dry oaky finish.  Very nice beer.

Bottle at De Kelk. This orange ale poured into a Tjseeses glass with a foamy beige head and an apricot aroma.   The flavor is almost undescribable, but I¬íll try. Fruity, thick, spicy, caramel malt, oak. Overall, delicious.

33 cl bottle at hotel room in Copenhagen, June 2009. As ¬´No. 11 xmas¬ª. Hazy orange/brown color, big off-white head. Aroma is fruity, citric, malty, spicy and yeasty. Flavor is fruity, citrus, spices, hints of sourness, sweetness, yeast, oak and some alcohol. Balanced and very fine beer.

7/16/2009:  Struise Tsjeeses Reserva has soft plum and flat caramel in its aroma.  The beer has a cloudy orange-amber color and a bubbly off-white crown.  It tastes pretty good and has dried dates, caramelized sugars, hints of Christmas-like spices (nutmeg, allspice, etc.), and hints of smoke/char in its medley of flavor.  It finishes dry and woody.  This medium-bodied beer has an airy mouth feel.  Overall I enjoyed this beer, but it seemed to be lacking complexity/depth.
33 cl bottle (Alc 10% Vol; TSJ no 11 X-Max Brew; Aged 6 months on oak) shared by alexsdad06.  Thanks!  Rating #127 for this beer.

Rating 3800. Bottle at De Kelk in Brugge. Served in a 18" chalice. Very hazy brown/amber with floaties. Fruit aromas. Maybe a touch of wood. Full bodied with creamy carbonation. Mild oak flavor with lots of fresh fruit. Touch of heat. Very smooth - almost vinous. Finishes towards bitter, and surprisingly dry. Flavors linger on. Really good.

From the bottle flows a hazy, glowing, deep amber liquid, substantial in body and crowned with a whipped head of off-white froth.  Bunching at the edges, the bubbly foam leaves sticky, jagged lines of jagged lacing that resemble lightning strikes across the sky.  The nose is centered in well caramelized candy sugars, though soft, vanilla-laden oak asserts significant influence.  Funk and citrus elements present in the regular version are mellowed considerably by the assertive, yet delicate wood.  Flavors too are sweet, soft, and easy-going.  Bronzed, blonde candy sugar, oak, and distant hints of maple are most prominent, though some spicy citrus peel and faint coriander are also there.  Dangerously drinkable for a 10% ABV brew, the palate is both smooth and substantial, without any annoying stickiness.  A subtle alcohol burn is all that holds it back.  One of the better tripels I¬íve encountered in ages, this is an entirely different animal than the non-oaked version of Tsjeeses.  Different, yet equal, in all material respects.  Very good brew.
Bottle. High fluffy but lasting white head. Hazy muddy amber body. Sweet fruity herbal spicy aroma and flavor with high carbonation, a hint of alcohol and a long aftertaste.

Bottle, 33cl. Pours an unclear beer with floating chunks. The head is offwhite. The aroma is fruity with esters and some acidity. The flavor is sweet with spices and vanilla. The palate is sweet. Overall a funny beer.

Bottle courtesy of fiver29 ¬ñ thanks John!  Pours a murky orange with a one finger light tan head.  The nose is fruit, light spice and yeast.  The taste is ripe fruit, earthy yeast, Belgian spice and rock candy with just a touch of floral hops in the finish.  Medium creamy mouthfeel.  Very nice, better than the regular version.  Hide the ABV well but is definitely a warmer.  Thanks again John for the opportunity to try this!

Bottle @ Delirium.  Pours hazy amber with sediment after gushing.  Aroma is a bit winey and spicy.  Taste is sweet with raisins, apples, and what seemed like oxidative notes.  Pretty hefty and full with alcohol.  Finish is spicy and warming.  I found this beer to be very complex, yet I really couldn¬ít get behind this beer.

Colore arancio-ambrato un p√≤ velato e schiuma bianca e spumosa. L¬íaroma √® fruttato,accento di vaniglia, legno, spezie. Il gusto √® morbido e asciutto ben bilanciato. con sentori di spezie, morbido con sentori di frutta. Finale secco e con l¬íamaro del luppolo.Buona.

Bottle received via trade with Koelschtrinker.  Pours hazy orange with a large, frothy, white head, lasting with excellent lacing.  Aroma is average malt (straw, meal), light hop (grass), heavy yeast (earth, barnyard, horse blanket) with notes of oak, wine, and pear.  Full bodied, creamy texture, average carbonation, and an astringent finish.  Long duration, light sweetness and bitterness, moderate acidity.

330; thanks, After4ever. Pours cloudy golden amber with a thin white head. Slightly funky toffee and yeast nose. Full body, nearly still. Very sweet taste of toffee, backed by some nutty and prune bits. Not as well balanced as I¬íd like.

330; thanks, TheWolf! Pours a murky medium amber. Headless, laceless. Toffee, creamy nose with a tiny bit of funk there. Creamy medium body, almost sticky. Oak notes, a wee bit of carb, toffee, butterscotch on the mid-palate. Long acetic oaky finish.

33 cl bottle.  Five seconds after uncapping white foam began to materialize and push its way slowly up the neck.  Poured a murky brown with a rather tame head.  Nose is soft caramel and dough with hints of sherry, cheese and mushroom.  Medium body with lively carb.  Taste is apricot, candied orange peel, sour mash and bitter herbs.  Complex and unique with a delightful sweetness.

from crackedkettle.com - cloudy dark orange colour under a solid bright white foam; beautiful lace; aroma of yeast and peaches with notes of wood and apples; very sweet and with a robust malt body, slightly oily, long fruity and woody finish with tons of residual sugars - too sweet to be really great
Cloudy orange colour with a white head. malty, spicy aroma with yeast and alcohol sweet notes, some pepper and oak hints. Malty, fruity and spicy flavor with notes of oak. Light dry yeasty finish.

A 0.33L bottle tasted at One Pint Pub. Beige head. Slightly sweet nose with some hints of vanilla. Floating particles. Sweet slightly sour taste. Well balanced. Some raisins in the taste. At the en hoppiness.
Bottle. Dark orange body, with a medium off-white head. Aroma is yeast, spices, some fruit. Flavor is fruit, yeast, spices, sweet caramel. It¬¥s a bit too sweet for me.

330ml bottle shared courtesy of egajdzis (thanks!). Poured a medium and hazy golden color with an averaged sized white head. Aromas of wood/oak, fruity, vanilla, citrus, and some spices. Tastes of candi sugar, lighter wood, spices, citrus, honey, and vanilla. Lighter alcohol in the finish but overall well hidden.

750mL bottle shared by ygtbsm94 in line at the Sexual Chocolate release.  Thanks Brad!!   Poured golden with a small white head. This beer was really interesting, as most are from this brewery. 33cl Bottle. Hazy golden color with a medium lacing off-white head. The aroma is fantastic lots of fruit,spices,oak,calvados, alcohol,malt, caramel. A pleasure. 330cl bottle shared by devon.  thank you sir.... pours a semi-transparent apple cider brown with a thin soapy white head...  aroma of sweet candied sugar liqueur, a little fruity paired with some toffee malt....flavors of sweet honey, cidery sweetness, bubblegum, and almost brandy-esque.  pretty nice and would like to try again.

botlte. big thanks to xnoxhatex for sharing. pours murky gold with white head. nose is apply, wood, caramel. flavors of apples, oak, vanilla, pinnapple, toffee. med body, alc in check, tasty stuff.

100th rating of this brew. Delicious stuff, much fuller in flavor than the non-reserva.  Sweet candi malt, slightly toasty, some light creamy stinky cheese, lovely hop spiciness.  Sweet and very flavorful.  Bigger feeling in body than the non-reserva, medium/full, fine sharp but sparse carbonation.  A true treat.
Cloudy orange in color with a decent sized white head. Aroma is of apple, funk, a little tartness, orange and spices. Taste is of malt, fruit, grain and spices.

The smell is fruits, apples, yeast, oak cask, and slight tartness.  The look is a muddy, apple pie colored, and has a ok head.  The taste is fruits, apples, yeast, tart.  I has hoping for a little more.

Poured a murky orange amber color with a thin film of off white head that left light lacing on the glass.  Aroma of  vanilla, oak, almonds, apples, caramel malts, honey, citrus.  Taste of honey, citrus, apples, vanilla, toffee, light spices, and a bit of alcohol in the finish.

Wow is this beer just like Stille Nacht or what?
33cl bottle from hopduvel @ Ghent. typical struise smell. strong alcohol taste with good malt no strong hop taste

Bottle pours cloudy amber color with a thin white head.  Aroma is slight fruit, spice, leather, and tobacco.  Has a medium mouthfeel.  Flavor is very complex.  There is a nice balance of fruit flavor.  Peach, banana, mandarin orange, with a touch of mango.  These fruit flavors meld together and finish with touch of white pepper. 750mL bottle, big thanks to my cousin, ggaughan! Pours hazy golden, with some sediment, capped with a small white head. Aroma of caramel, yeast, citrus, honey, oak, and  some spice. Orange colored brew. Aroma ripe fruits, oak, bourbon. Flavor is ripe fruits, sweetness, apple and some yeast. Nice.

Bottle. Cloudy orange with a dense and foamy white head. Aromas of spices, bread, wood and malt. The flavour is spicy with a fruity sweetness and notes of banana. All ended by a lightly sour woody freshness. Soft and and warming mouthfeel..

From 75cl bottle - Beautiful slightly hazy deep amber body, fine sparkle, creamy off white head that could last a little longer; Very fine nutty yeast soft nose with an almost Calvados sharpness and aroma accompanying, very nice; Very soft textured body with a big very soft carbonation, super balanced, could be a little more powerful; Medium long finish with a very special mild alcohol burn, again the Calvados barrel is there. rbesg08 grand tasting, bottled. hazy amber. aroma of cinnamon, nutmeg, clove and mandarin, plenty of yeast bite, thick and weird with some earthy cumin in the finish and some woody dryness

(33cl bottle, Batch Nr 97, BB 2020)  Pours a murky golden body with a small white head.  Aroma of rotten oranges, yeast, mustiness, and apricot.  Flavor of citrus, peach, yeast, and candi sugar with a dry oak finish.

Bottle. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Orange colour. Particles. Powerfull fruity yesty aroma. Moderate bitter flavor. Strong licorice and fruity notes. Long nice warming finish. Very creamy palate. Nice.

750 ml bottle shared generously by Eric at his holiday bash. Pours a cloudy orange with a thick foamy white head. A very nice nose of spices, cloves especially, light wood, bread and light malt. Bottle @ PlanB √òJ-dag. Pours a hazy light amber with a tiny diminishing white head. Smells of fruits and alcohol. Sweet and malty with aromas of fruits and a hint of glue. UPDATED: DEC 23, 2010 Drank right after the Tsjeeses, and I think I am one of the few that prefers the original. Lighter color, hazy orange with another nice white head, more soapy this time and still loads of lacing. Very refreshing nose, more sour than tripel with the lactic and fruit dominating. The flavor is more like the regular Tsjeeses, tripel qualities returning while sweetly balanced with orange. The alcohol is also more of a factor, slightly distracting. A little stickier and dryer than the Tsjeeses, though still full bodied, smooth, and alive. Finish is more lactic, still rather long. This is delicious, but I think the brilliantly restrained harmony and sheer grape delight of the Tsjeeses have been lost while aging. Several tries later, it¬ís too hot, with too much off-setting syrupy fruit sweetness. Tripel is unmarried to fruit as well (see Splinter Gold for a shattering example).
Bottle. Big thanks to MrChopin for this treat. Aroma of sweet fruits, jackfruit. Starts off sweet with fruit tones followed by vanilla oak and a perfect hop bitter finish. Wonderful

Fresh bottle back-to-back with the not-Reserva. Unexplosive conditioning for Struise- puffs anticlimactically open with an unmessy hiss, all the beer kept in the bottle. Didnt even need the Hoey pintpot this time. Deep honey amber with a slick stable head and specks of lace. M/f slick and velvety as before. Mellower, cleaner, more grape and fig-sodden aroma approaching 5* Metaxa brandy. Apricot jam, ginger and freshly chopped oak. Seriously fine-smelling ale. Bulbous juicy stonefruit, ripe nectarine, fig, creamy vanilla brandy and oak smokiness. Evil fig and brandy milkshake palate without a sniff of booze. Again some soapy spice which could include ginger, aniseed or cardamom, but im looking for it. Much more integrated brew than the 2yr old Tsjeeses. A lovely ripe Stille Nacht shandy of a beer.

Hazy amber with a small lacing head. Sweet nose, candy, fruity esters, bit yeasty. Full bodied yet drinkable and smooth, spicy and a fruity maltiness toward a complex end. Expect more dryness for the style.
Bottle thanks to bu11zeye. Another really hard to find one. Gray yellow colored pour. Nose is sour, metal, and powdered sugar. and fruits. Taste is creamy, and of grapes, caramel and booze.

Bottle thanks to bu11zeye. Pours with a huge white head and a hazy golden body. Aroma  of oak, dark fruit, apple, pear and raisin. Taste is caramel, fruits, dates, and alcohol. Syrupy and lightly carbonated.

wow thanks again bu11zeye.  murky amber pour and a white head.  fruity nose with some notes of wood. smooth on the palate with a fruity almost tart flavor with some wood.  nice finish of fruit and wood.

Hazy orange with a low head. The aroma is spicy (weed?) and full of wood and some herbs. A huge body is the first impression, drinking this triple. then the flavours start kicking in. Again the spice is dominating combined with different types of herbs and some oak.

Bottle. Large creamy off-white head that mostly lasted. Good display of lacework. Cloudy golden color. Aroma was very apricot ¬ñ fruity, with vinous and wood like notes. After the beer warmed up, a bit of the finish almost felt like liquorish on the tong.
UPDATED: APR 17, 2009 ripe fruit (prumes, dates) in the nose, in the flavor spicy and almost smokey, pure heaven

Smooth as hell and rediculously easy to drink for such a strong beer.  Much better than anticipated- and one of my new favorite tripels. UPDATED: SEP 16, 2011 33cl, Vintage 2010, exclusive brew, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex X-Mas brew, balanced, cloudy, small head, very good brew

Muddy orange with a small white head. Fresh and fruity yeast aroma with citrus, pineapple, bubblegum and some herbal hop notes. Flavour is fruity and spicy with alcohol and a slightly tannic dry finish.

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2011 (Bottle) Pours hazy golden amber. The aroma is heavily floral and medium sweet with a complex tropical fruitiness of mango and peach alongside notes of spices, wood and vanilla. Bottle from miketd‚Äôs tasting

i don‚Äôt know how he continues to get such a stellar array of beers but once again Mike came through with a Struisse release that is worth trying.  I hope at some point the regular Tsjeeses makes it to the United States so I can see what effect the aging has had on it.  This one is worth the hype if you can find it.

Aroma / Appearance - A cloudy brown body swirls fluidly around the glass releasing the smell of banana bread, fruit and malt into the air.  Complete in every way there is nothing lacking that I could find.

Flavor / Palate - The first sip was a rich blend of yeast, nuttiness, dark chocolate and a hint of woodiness.  The yeasty finish caps off an excellent experience that stands among the best in the world.  Hopefully this will be released again in wider circles.

Bottled @ RBESG Grand Tasting 2008. Hazy and amber coloured with a rather large off-white head. Very fruity with notes of honey, yeast, spices and quite tart and dry. I - for one - think this beer is somewhat hyped. Not too well balanced.

Bottle, 75 cl. (Bought @ Vanden Bussche, Waregem)
Hazy amber with great off-white head. Medium to full body. 
Taste sweet, spices, very dry, alcoholic, complex (fruits), also wood notes.

Bottle (RBESG 08): Turpentine, yeast fruits and hops in the nose; full bitter-sweet flavour, full bodied, too; bitter and a bit tart in the aftertaste. Complex and balanced brew........

UPDATED: DEC 17, 2016 Drank this brew a couple of times!  Once on tap at the Waregem beerfest (08), and also at the Struise farm from a 75cl bottle.  Both tastings had a hazy orange/apricot color.  From the tap though, the head just exploded with a superb creamy head that settles into a thin layer.  The bottled was a little more restrained than on tap. The beer pours a fantastic orange and reddish color and the beautiful off white head stay for ever on this most aromatic nectar. The smell is very complex with lots of cookie aromas touches of nuts, honey, spices (?),  red berries, wood, wet dog, sigarecase, some peppery yeast and ripe peaches. Taste is rich and elegant with hints of bread, croisants, red berries, pits of stonefruits, wood, cedar, mint and soft hops. A rich taste with a dry wood caracter that works perfect. This was the best of the session.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2012 Bottle shared by Urbain at Struise farm. Incredibly huge nose of oak wine barrels, red grapes and black cherries... huge tannic nose, dry oak, deep, rich, extremely complex wine character on top of an equally impressive Belgian golden/trippel... but honestly the transformation of this beer from base version to reserva is a miracle... vinous, wondrous, smooth and rich, with a huge, tannic oak wine barrel dryness... amazingly deep and complex, a truly stellar beer.

750ml bottle at London tasting, May 2008. BBE 12 December 2012. Many thanks to Mes for this one. Poured a rather murky orange colour but I think I got the last sample so I¬íll forgive it that. Massive aroma - estery fruit, tangy hops, subtle spices, some vinous woody touches and even a suggestion of volatile Airfix glue. Not too much vanilla, which is fine by me as I often find oak aged beers have just too much vanilla for my taste. Taste is pretty much like the aroma - bags of sharp fruit. Robust body with a pleasant sweet (but not too sweet) and sour (but not too sour) mouthfeel. Oak aging frequently seems to me a bit of a gimmick, too often failing to add anything worthwhile to the underlying beer, but that is not the case here. The woody element combines with the fruity character together seamlessly. A beautifully crafted beer in very respect.

A Mes rate: Bottle at the Oi Oi Saveloy tasting at Chris O¬ís.The fifth bottle I have tried of this and although I do feel it varies a little they have all been stunning, but I wouldn¬ít expect anything less.Semi hazy orange amber colour with a thin wisp of head and lots of legs.The aroma is absolutely amazing. Slight wood, stunning vanilla, lovely alcohol, creamy caramel, barley sugar, incredible fruit and just an abundance of complexity. The balance is nothing short of perfect, there is so much going on but nothing jumps out at you. An easy 10.The flavour follows on well. There is some utterly incredible sourness from the wood. Very delicate but perfect. Amazing alcohol that gives such warmth and a wonderful glow on the way down. Again it¬ís just perfectly balanced. Yet more genius from Struise.The mouthfeel is perfect. The dryness is stunning. I could quite happily make myself very messy on this.Bloody excellent.

At May Ratebeer London Gathering at Chris O¬ís. Hazy caramel colour with a small white head. Sweet fruity alcoholic aroma with some glue (Thanks for that prompt, Chris). The aroma scores a rare 10. Sweet caramel taste, quite fizzy, and leading into a sour, bitter finish with orange peel. My top beer of the Gathering: a wonderful experience. I¬ím privileged to have tried it.

Bottled at the Struise farm.  Hazy amber, small head. Funky orange aroma. Sweet and full bodied. Complex flavour with orange, cinnamon, honey, grain and vanilla. Very lively and fruity. Juicy with concentrated, yet remaing very drinkable. Excellent beer!
